concepts.interpretation: A 'tribunal' under Art. 136(1) is an authority constituted by the State and invested with the State's inherent judicial power to adjudicate disputes between parties, distinct from courts or purely administrative bodies.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Sharma in accordance with the provisions of the Rules for such acts and companymissions on his part as may have companye to their numberice. It is th

anchor.surface_text: Art.136 1  refers to a tribunal as distinguished from a court. The expression court in the context denotes a tribunal .constituted by the State as a part of the ordinary hierarchy of ,courts which are invested with the States inherent judicial powers.

concepts.interpretation: Art. 136(1) empowers Supreme Court to grant special leave to appeal from any tribunal exercising judicial functions.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with questions as to whether any impugned orders could be revised under Art. 226 of our Constitution, the test prescribed by Lord Reid in this judgment may afford considerable assistance.

In Nagendra Nath Bora Another v. The Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam, Ors.  1  this Court had to consider whether the jurisdiction of the High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution could be invoked
Under the provisions of the Factories Act, 1948  No. 63 of 1948   hereinafter called the Act  read with the provisions of the Rules, the appellant was required to appoint one Welfare Officer

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-rule  2  the management may impose any one or more of the following punishments on Welfare Officers Censure Withholding of increments including stoppage at an efficiency bar reduction to a lower stage in a time scale suspension and dismissal or termination of service in any other manner

concepts.interpretation: Lists punishments including dismissal/termination; requires Labour Commissioner's concurrence except for censure; termination here was simple discharge, not punishment.

anchor.surface_text: but the authority to reach decisions conferred on such administrative bodies is clearly distinct and separate from the judicial power conferred on courts, and the decisions pronounced by administrative bodies are similarly distinct and separate in character from judicial decisions.

anchor.surface_text: the condition precedent, said Mahajan J., for bringing a tribunal within the ambit of Art. 136 is that it should be constituted by the State. Again, a tribunal would be outside the ambit of Art. 136 if it is not invested with any part of the judicial functions of the State but discharges purely administrative or executive duties

issues.text: whether respondent No. 2, the State of Punjab, exercising its appellate jurisdiction under Rule 6(6) of the Punjab Welfare Officers Recruitment and Conditions of Service Rules, 1952 (hereinafter called the Rules) is a Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136(1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, C. J. The principal point of law which arises in this appeal by special leave is whether respondent No. 2, the State of Punjab, exercising its appellate jurisdiction under Rule 6 6  of the Punjab Welfare Officers Recruitment and Conditi

issues.text: whether the relevant Rule which requires the concurrence of the Labour Commissioner before the management can dismiss or terminate the services of a Welfare Officer, is invalid inasmuch as it is outside the scope of the authority conferred on the State Government by s. 49(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The termination of respondent No. 1s services in terms of clause 4 of his conditions of service is no more than a discharge, and as such is not a punishment and so, it is outside r. 6 3  altogether.

arguments.claim: State Government under R.6(6) is tribunal under Art.136(1) as exercises State's judicial power

anchor.surface_text: The principal point of law which arises in this appeal by special leave is whether respondent No. 2, the State of Punjab, exercising its appellate jurisdiction under Rule 6 6  of the Punjab Welfare Officers Recruitment and Conditions of Service Rules, 1952  hereinafter called the Rules  is a Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136 1  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Tribunal under Art.136 constituted by State, invested with judicial functions distinguishing from administrative

anchor.surface_text: Art.136 1  refers to a tribunal as distinguished from a court. The expression court in the context denotes a tribunal .constituted by the State as a part of the ordinary hierarchy of ,courts which are invested with the States inherent judicial powers.

arguments.claim: Following Bharat Bank: Industrial Tribunal is tribunal under Art.136

anchor.surface_text: The first decision where this question was elaborately companysidered was pronounced in the case of The Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi, v. Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., and the Bharat Bank Employees Union, Delhi 1 . In that case, an award pronounced by an Industrial Tribunal

arguments.claim: R.6(6) confers judicial power: lis between parties, final binding decision

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to these distinctive features of the power companyferred on the State Government by R. 6 5  and R. 6 6 , we feel numberhesitation in holding that it is a Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136 1 .

arguments.claim: Bachawat: Basic test for tribunal is vesting with judicial power of State

anchor.surface_text: In this background, the basic test of a tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136 is that it is an adjudicating authority  other than a Court  vested with the judicial powers of the State.

arguments.claim: Bachawat: State under R.6(6) vested with judicial power, acts judicially on lis

anchor.surface_text: A companysideration of all these matters shows that the State Government deciding an appeal under R. 6 6  of the Service Rules is vested with the judicial powers of the State, and satisfies the test of a tribunal as companytemplated by Art. 136 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Lower court: Reinstate respondent No.1 as punishment imposed warranting appeal

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 then passed the impugned order on July 4, 1962. This order was issued in the name of the Governor of Punjab in exercise of the powers companyferred by R. 6 6  of the Rules, and it directed that the Governor of Punjab was pleased to reinstate respondent No. 1 as Labour Welfare Officer in the service of the appellant. Ho

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the parties in relation to each other is number to be regarded as a judicial power of the Commonwealth within Art. 71 of the Australian Constituti

arguments.court_reasoning: No punishment; simple discharge; appeal incompetent

holdings.text: The State Government exercising appellate jurisdiction under Rule 6(6) of the Punjab Welfare Officers Recruitment and Conditions of Service Rules, 1952 is a Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to these distinctive features of the power conferred on the State Government by R. 6(5) and R. 6(6), we feel no hesitation in holding that it is a Tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Government decides lis between parties on punishment appeals, exercises part of State's inherent judicial power, final and binding decision; follows precedents like Bharat Bank, Harinagar Sugar Mills.

holdings.text: Rule 6 requiring concurrence of Labour Commissioner before dismissal/termination of Welfare Officer is valid and within scope of s.49(2) Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are not impressed by Mr. Setalvads argument that the Rule in question is ultra vires or invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Conditions of service' in s.49(2) wide enough to cover termination conditions and safeguards like concurrence for security of tenure.

holdings.text: The termination of respondent No.1's services was a simple discharge under terms of appointment, not a punishment under Rule 6(3)(v).

anchor.surface_text: The termination of respondent No. 1s services in terms of clause 4 of his conditions of service is no more than a discharge, and as such is not a punishment and so, it is outside r. 6(3) altogether.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination per clause 4 (one month's pay in lieu), no inquiry or charge, no slur or improper motive; distinguishes punitive from contractual discharge.

holdings.text: Appeal by respondent No.1 under Rule 6(6) incompetent as no punishment imposed.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the appeal preferred by respondent No. 1 before respondent No. 2 was not competent under rule 6(6).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 6(6) appeal only against punishment under 6(3)(v); simple discharge outside scope.

holdings.text: Impugned order passed by respondent No.2 set aside as without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, and the impugned order passed by respondent No. 2 is set aside on the ground that it has been passed without jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Flows from incompetent appeal; State Govt lacked jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Bachawat J concurs: State Government under R.6(6) is tribunal under Art.136 as vested with judicial powers of State.

anchor.surface_text: In this background, the basic test of a tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136 is that it is an adjudicating authority other than a Court vested with the judicial powers of the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate opinion agreeing; basic test is vesting of State's judicial power to conclusively determine rights in lis; trappings not essential.

justification_sets.label: Punjab Welfare Officers Rules Rule 6(3) support

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, and the impugned order passed by respondent No. 2 is set aside on the that it has been passed without Jurisdiction. Parties to bear their own companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; impugned order of State Government set aside as passed without jurisdiction because the employee's appeal was incompetent (termination was simple discharge under contract, not punishment)

edges.explanation: Holding that appeal incompetent addresses the issue of appeal competence.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the appeal preferred by respondent No. 1 before respondent No. 2 was not competent under rule 6(6).
The result is, the appeal is allowed, and the impugned order passed by respondent No. 2 is set aside on the that it has been passed without Jurisdiction. Parties to bear their own companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 concurs that the State Government under R.6(6) is a tribunal under Art.136, addressing the same issue i1.

anchor.surface_text: In this background, the basic test of a tribunal within the meaning of Art. 136 is that it is an adjudicating authority other than a Court vested with the judicial powers of the State.
The result is, the appeal is allowed, and the impugned order passed by respondent No. 2 is set aside on the that it has been passed without Jurisdiction. Parties to bear their own companyts.
